text: And take not the word of truth utterly out of my mouth; for I have hoped in thy judgments.
text_kjv: And take not the word of truth utterly out of my mouth; for I have hoped in thy judgments.
text_niv: Do not snatch the word of truth from my mouth,for I have put my hope in your laws.
text_esv: And take not the word of truth utterly out of my mouth, for my hope is in your rules.
text_nlt: Do not snatch your word of truth from me,for your regulations are my only hope.
text_msg: Don't ever deprive me of truth, not ever—your commandments are what I depend on.
text_nasb: And do not take the word of truth utterly out of my mouth, For I wait for Your ordinances.
context: Psalm 119, the longest psalm, is an acrostic poem, with each of its 22 sections (eight verses each) corresponding to a letter of the Hebrew alphabet. This psalm is a hymn extolling the beauty and importance of God's law (Torah), encompassing His teachings, statutes, commandments, and judgments. The Psalmist consistently expresses a deep love for and commitment to God's word as a source of guidance, comfort, and hope. The historical context is likely post-exilic, reflecting a time when the Jewish people were rebuilding their lives and faith amidst challenging circumstances. The emphasis on the Law suggests a desire to maintain their identity and relationship with God after experiencing national trauma. In ancient Israel, memorization and oral transmission of scripture were crucial, given the scarcity of written texts. The phrase 'my mouth' implies both personal confession and public proclamation of faith. The 'judgments' mentioned weren't necessarily punitive but encompass God's righteous decrees and decisions guiding righteous living. Understanding the psalm requires appreciation for the Hebrew emphasis on the Torah not as legalistic constraint, but as a loving instruction manual for life. Hope in God's judgments, rather than human solutions, was a common theme during times of national crisis and personal struggles.
meaning: Psalm 119:43 encapsulates a powerful plea for divine assistance in maintaining faithfulness to God's truth. The Psalmist's cry, 'And take not the word of truth utterly out of my mouth,' underscores the vital role of verbal testimony and proclamation in preserving faith. It suggests a fear of losing the ability or the courage to speak God's truth, possibly due to external pressures or internal doubts. This isn't simply about possessing knowledge of truth, but actively articulating and sharing it. The phrase 'word of truth' highlights the reliability and trustworthiness of God's revealed will, contrasting it with falsehood and deception. The petition acknowledges human frailty and dependence on God's sustaining grace to remain steadfast in proclaiming His word. The subsequent phrase, 'for I have hoped in thy judgments,' provides the foundation for this request. The Psalmist isn't demanding entitlement but appealing to God's established character of justice and faithfulness. His hope isn't in fleeting emotions or favorable circumstances, but in God's consistent and righteous decrees. By trusting in God's judgments, the Psalmist demonstrates a commitment to living according to God's ways, making his plea for continued faithfulness a natural consequence of his devotion. The verse reveals a reciprocal relationship: hope in God's judgments empowers the believer to speak God's truth, and speaking God's truth reinforces hope in God's judgments.
application: In today's complex world, Psalm 119:43 carries profound relevance. We face constant pressures to compromise our values, remain silent in the face of injustice, or distort the truth to fit popular opinion. The Psalmist's prayer becomes our prayer – 'And take not the word of truth utterly out of my mouth.' This means actively engaging with Scripture, not just passively reading it. It requires meditating on its meaning, internalizing its principles, and allowing it to shape our thoughts, words, and actions. It also calls for courageous articulation of biblical truth in various contexts: in our families, workplaces, communities, and even online platforms. Speaking truth doesn't necessarily mean being confrontational or judgmental. It can involve offering compassionate counsel, standing up for the marginalized, or simply living with integrity and authenticity. The Psalmist's hope in God's judgments becomes our anchor in times of uncertainty. When the world around us seems chaotic and confusing, we can find stability in God's unchanging character and righteous decrees. This hope isn't passive wishful thinking but an active trust that God is working all things together for good, even when we cannot see the bigger picture. Practically, this means aligning our lives with biblical principles, even when it's difficult or unpopular. It requires resisting the temptation to compromise our values for personal gain or social acceptance. It also involves seeking God's wisdom and guidance in every decision we make, trusting that He will lead us in the path of righteousness. Furthermore, it is important to create supportive environments in our lives with other believers where truth is valued, and courageous speaking is encouraged. Regularly praying for the boldness and opportunity to share the gospel. Ultimately, Psalm 119:43 reminds us that our ability to speak God's truth is a gift, not a right, and it is sustained by our hope in His unwavering justice and love.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I come before you with a humble heart, acknowledging my dependence on your grace. Lord, I pray that you would not allow the word of truth to be silenced in my life. Give me the courage to speak your truth, even when it is difficult or unpopular. Strengthen my faith in your judgments, knowing that you are just and righteous in all your ways. Help me to live a life that reflects your love and grace, so that my words will be a testament to your goodness. Lord, fill my heart with compassion for those who are lost and hurting, and give me the wisdom to share your truth in a way that is both loving and effective. I pray this in the name of Jesus Christ, my Lord and Savior. Amen.

faqs.answer: It signifies a loss of ability or willingness to proclaim God's truth. This could be due to fear, doubt, societal pressure, or spiritual apathy. It suggests a severing of the connection between internal belief and external expression, rendering one silent or compromised in their testimony.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: What does it mean to have the 'word of truth utterly out of my mouth'?

faqs.answer: Hoping in God's judgments provides the foundation for speaking truth. It fosters trust in God's righteousness and assures us that truth will ultimately prevail. This conviction emboldens us to speak God's truth, even amidst opposition, because we know God is just.
faqs.question: Q2: How does 'hoping in God's judgments' relate to speaking the truth?

faqs.answer: Social media echo chambers, fear of cancel culture, pressure to conform to secular ideologies, and the desire for personal gain or social acceptance can all create environments where it becomes difficult to speak biblical truth freely and openly.
faqs.question: Q3: What are some modern examples of pressures that might cause us to 'lose' the word of truth from our mouths?

faqs.answer: Regularly study scripture, meditate on its meaning, pray for boldness to share it, associate with believers who value truth, and seek opportunities to serve and speak in accordance with God's will in your community.
faqs.question: Q4: How can we practically cultivate a life where God's Word remains actively in our mouths?

faqs.answer: While personal salvation is foundational, the verse also speaks to societal transformation. By remaining faithful to truth, believers become agents of change, influencing society with God's principles and working towards a more just world. It works interdependently.
